titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. At the Bankrupt Office at 10. this morning. 1st: Meeting, William Neal— He surrendered but no creditors appeared. Forenoon at my Office— Afternoon called at the Post-Office— Made out for J. Peck the form of an Affidavit. Went out with Mrs: Adams and the child to Quincy— Walking in the Mall this morning I met numbers of people, who had come out, as on May Morning; but the weather was very cold, and the wind boisterous— I had not been aware that any notice was ever taken of May-day, in this Country.
2. Heard Mr: Whitney the whole day— Consulted the article Ship-building in the Encyclopaedia.— My Uncle Adams with us part of the evening.— Read to my father part of the address to the fire Society.

3. Return’d to Boston early this morning. Met at the Commission Office at 11. A.M. 3d: meeting in the case of John Soley: adjourn’d to this day week— Met again at 4. in the afternoon. Adjourn’d third meeting for Roylance Child— We were obliged to adjourn again, to receive a statement of a partnership in England, to which he belongs— We are to meet on the 1st: of September— I went to the Bank and took out bills, which I sent out by Dexter to my father— Remainder of the afternoon at my Office— Mr: Babcock called there— Evening at home, writing.

4. Sworn as Commissioner in the case of W. P. Smith— Employed the greater part of the day in drawing up Mr: Babcock’s papers. Mr: Black called at my Office, and took the indentures I had drawn for him— Mr: Dunlap called on me this afternoon with General Elliot— S. Blodget likewise called— Evening at home.— Called on Mr: Parsons this morning.

5. Private meeting in the case of W. P. Smith, at 1/2 past 9 this morning.— Found him bankrupt— Mr: Babcock and Mr: Dunlap, called at my Office— Engaged the greatest part of the day upon their business— Letter from T. B. Johnson this afternoon. Called at Mr: Lowell’s office, relative to Dunlap’s business— Evening at the Club, at Mr: Welles’s.

6. Forenoon at my office— Mr: Dunlap and Mr: Boylston called there— Discussion with J. Hall at his Office— Dined at Mr: E. Gray’s. Mr: Peck, judge Dawes, and judge Davis were there.— Meeting of Comrs: at 4. in the afternoon; in the case of W. P. Smith— Charles Paine the petitioning creditor appointed provisional assignee— Afterwards an hour at my office again. Walk’d in the Mall— Evening at home.

7. Drew bond for Mr: Babcock to be left at Taylor’s insurance office— Called on Judge Sullivan respecting the settlement of the trustees of J. Boylston’s Will—their demand against Mr: Gill— Referred to the week after next. Met Commissioner in the case of R. Dixon, at 4. this afternoon— Evening at the Society— Mr: Popkin lectured to us upon Volta’s condensing plates: but the experiments did not altogether succeed, for want of electrometers of sufficient sensibility— Judge Lowell died this morning.

8. Mr: Boylston and judge Davis called upon me this forenoon—2d: meeting of Commissioners in the case of J. Vinal junr: His father being the only voting creditor chose himself Assignee— Executed assignment of W. P. Smith’s effects to Charles Paine— W. Shaw went to Quincy this afternoon— Spent it at my office— Evening at home.

9. Attended at Mr: Emerson’s and heard Mr: Willard the librarian of Harvard University— Mrs: Adams went in the afternoon— Walk in the mall— Met F. Bradbury, and my old fellow-student T. Thompson. Called in the evening, for half an hour at Mr: Storer’s—remainder of it at home.

10. Commissioners office in the forenoon, at 10. Meeting of W. P. Smith’s creditors— In the afternoon, adjourn’d 3d: meeting for John Soley— Attended at the probate-office before noon and after— Likewise at the funeral of judge Lowell— Walk’d with T. Williams— Evening at home.

11. Morning at my office— At 4. in the afternoon, attended as a bearer, the funeral of Mr: William Gordon, late a member of Congress from the State of New-Hampshire, and attorney-General of that State— The other bearers were Judges Davis, Dawes, and Livermore, Mr: T. Bigelow and Mr: Thompson— He was buried from Mr: James Prince’s, at whose request I attended, never having had any personal acquaintance with him.— Afterwards at my Office— J. Gardner there— Caucus at Concert Hall, to agree upon a list of representatives; but I did not attend— Mrs: Adams at last received letters from her mother and sister.

12. Town meeting for the choice of representatives. The federal list, was carried by a majority of about 350 votes. Mr: Boylston, Townsend, and J. Gardner called upon me— Dined at Mr: B. Joy’s, in company with about twenty gentlemen— Club this evening with me— Only six or seven of the gentlemen came— A very stormy evening, with heavy, and highly seasonable rain— Had a letter from Mr: Hellen.

13. J. Gardner and Townsend were with me at my office most of the forenoon, and again towards Evening. Plodding over Mr: Babcock’s business, and other questions in litigation— Mr: Woodward call’d at my house late in the Evening.

14. Drew a deed for Mr: Woodward which he call’d and took— Third meeting of Commissioners for William Micklefield, at 11. this forenoon— Rest of the day at my Office, attending as much to business as I could— In the Evening our Society met; but Mr Williams the lecturer being absent, we had no experiments made— We agreed to commence upon some mathematical subjects.
15. Opened a Commission against James Campbell— Remainder of the morning chiefly at my office— In the afternoon went out with Mrs: Adams to Quincy; took the child with us likewise.

16. Mr: Cushing of Waltham preached— I heard him in the forenoon— He dined at my father’s— In the afternoon I walk’d over to Milton, to J. Gardner’s, and spent the evening with him— He return’d most of the way with me.

17. N. Curtis consulted me respecting some deeds he has taken— I am afraid he will suffer injustice for deficiency of forms. Return’d to Boston early this morning— At 9 1/2 had a meeting in the case of James Campbell; but the act of bankruptcy was not proved by competent evidence, and we adjourn’d untill to-morrow. The rest of the day, I was almost all the time at the probate office, upon the cases of Shaw, and M’Intire. Shaw’s was at length settled— M’Intire had been to Mr: Parsons for a clue to extricate him from his embarassments, and Parsons had furnished him the best he could find— Strengthened with this auxiliary Gray came out quite boldly with what he thought defence, but it proved only to be evasion— He was obliged at length to ask another week to produce vouchers, which he would gladly have refused.— Gray and his client both intimated that they had got from Parsons a complete defence upon the real action, but kept it snug, to produce in due time— I was greatly dissatisfied with myself in the management of this cause; for want of coolness, self-command, and method— Evening at home— Wrote to Mr: Hellen.

18. Was roused at about 2 o’clock in the morning by the cry of fire— I rose and went out, but it was extinguish’d before I reached the place— Return’d to bed, but had no further repose— This morning, quite unwell with a rhumatism— At my Office most of the day— Evening at home reading, and writing.

19. At the Office of the Commissioners in the cases of W. Micklefield, Ichabod Frost and James Campbell.— Dined with Quincy— At the chapel church this afternoon— Evening at the club at R. Amory’s. Suffered a good deal with the rhumatism.

20. Commissioner’s office this afternoon in the case of W. Neal— Rest of the day reading Marshall on Insurance, and the second volume of Blackstone.— At the chapel in the morning, and walk’d, at the beginning of the evening— The rest of it at home.

21. Finish’d reading the first volume of Marshall on insurance. In the afternoon at the bankrupt-office. Second meeting for W. P. Smith— C. Paine chosen assignee— Meeting of the Society this evening. We agreed to omit meeting next week— It being election week— And in the mean time to continue our algebraic pursuits.

22. First meeting of Commissioners in the case of John Vinall junr: James Campbell— Afterwards opened a Commission against Patrick Phillips— At 4 in the afternoon I went with Mr: Smith, and met the Attorney General (Sullivan) at Mr: Gill’s, to settle the demand of John Boylston’s surviving Exor: against the late Mr: Gill’s estate— In the evening I went out with J. Gardner to Quincy.

23. Heavy rain and stormy weather almost through the whole day. Heard Mr: Whitney in the afternoon— Past the remainder of the day in the Office, looking over some mathematical books, and reading Amyot’s translation of Plutarch’s treatise upon the education of children.

24. Return’d to Boston with Mrs: Adams and the child, early this morning— Third meeting of Comrs: in the case of John Vinall junr:— Mr: Thomas was at my office. In the afternoon at the probate office again upon M’Intire’s case— Walk’d in the Mall with Quincy— Judge Dawes call’d on me in the evening.

25. At the Commissioners office, from 9 to eleven this morning; upon several cases— One new one—of J. W. Blanchard. Attended the meeting of the Academy, from 12 to 2— The annual choice of officers was made— Professor Pearson, the corresponding Secretary, produced a latin letter from professor Heyne of Gottingen, the hand-writing of which he was unable to decypher— It accompanied some volumes of the transactions of the Gottingen Society. The former year’s officers were re-elected; but Mr: Pearson declined serving any longer, and the duties of the corresponding Secretary were assigned to me— My father whom I had expected did not come to town—probably deterred by the bad weather— Spent the afternoon at my Office, examining the Statute Law, applicable to M’Intyer’s case.

26. This being the day of General Election, at 9 in the morning I repaired to the Senate chamber, conformably to a summons which I received from the Governor on the 10th: of this month— In the course of an hour 34 of the Senators chosen had assembled— The Governor then came and administered to us the oaths required by the Constitution— He was attended by five members of the Council— After he had withdrawn The Senate being formed unanimously chose Genl: David Cobb, their President— Geo: E. Vaughan was next chosen as clerk— A verbal message was then sent to the House of Representatives to inform them of these appointments, and a Committee of three, sent to the Governor with a similar message— Soon after, a verbal message came from the house to inform the Senate that they had chosen John Coffin Jones their speaker and Henry Warren, clerk.— A Committee of the Senate was raised to examine and report the returns of Senators chosen—and three members for a joint Committee of the house and Senate to examine and report the returns of votes for Governor and Lieutenant Governor— A message was then sent to inform the Governor, that both houses were ready to attend him to hear divine service performed— The Governor and Council then came, and with both houses proceeded to the meeting house—where a sermon was preach’d by Mr: Baldwin, the chaplain of the house— At 4. in the afternoon the two houses met again— The Committee of the Senate made a report, by which it appears that there are 36 Senators chosen, and four places to be fill’d up by joint ballot of the two houses. The joint Committee had previously reported the election of Caleb Strong for Governor and Edward H. Robbins for Lieutenant Governor— Upon which a Committee was appointed to inform them of their being elected— A message was then sent to the House to inform them the Senate had assigned 1/2 past 6 this afternoon for the two houses to meet in Convention to supply the vacant places in the Senate, and request their concurrence; which was immediately brought by a message from them.— They met accordingly— The vacancies were fill’d by Mr: Frye in York County, Messrs Thompson and Hayward in Plymouth, and Mr: Dummer in Lincoln, Kennebeck and Washington— These elections being declared the Senate return’d to their chamber, ordered a notification to the Senators just elected, and adjourn’d untill 10. A.M. to-morrow— The proportion of votes for the candidates to the Senate was about 120 to 50.

My father was in town this day, but being so constantly engaged I did not see him— My wife was very ill all day, and in the evening, severely so with a sick head ache— I received a letter from T. B. Johnson.

27. The Senate met at 10 this morning— At about noon the joint committee appointed to notify the Governor and Lieutenant Governor of their election returned, and at 1/2 past 12 those officers appeared in the Convention of both houses— The oaths were administered to them by the President of the Senate, as President of the Convention, and immediately subscribed by them— The president of the Convention then announced to them that they were duly qualified, and asked whether they should be proclaimed as such which being assented to, he directed the Secretary to proclaim them, as he accordingly did— After which they withdrew; the Convention dissolved, and The Senate returned to their chamber. They immediately adjourn’d to 3 in the afternoon.— I dined at Mr: Emerson’s with about fifteen clergymen— At 4. went to the Bankrupt Office, and attended upon two cases— At 5. I found the houses in Convention had already made choice of nine counsellors from the Senate— The nine agreed upon in Caucus after the adjournment in the morning— I had there proposed to take two or three members, of opposite politics to our own, by way
of conciliatory proceedure; but no—they would not hear me— Lowell who must bring in Ames and Bigelow if he can very wisely proved the inexpediency of putting any Jacobin in the Council, upon general principles, and then himself proposed a Mr: Woodman from York County, a violent Jacobin, but who did not happen to interfere with any of his intended candidates.— The Caucus however were rather more consistent, and carried the principle through— The Counsellors elected are all federalists: four of them it is understood will resign, to bring in others from the people at large— After the choice of Counsellors in Convention was declared, the Senate returned to their hall—ordered notification to issue to the counsellors chosen, and adjourned to 9. to-morrow morning.— I afterwards went to Mr: Cooper’s Office, and acknowledged the instrument declining to serve as an Executor of Mr: Johnson’s Will— Cooper vented all his heart-burnings about Phillips, to me, and swore that he would at all events bring him in next year— Intimating that if the federalists would not bring him forward, the Jacobins should— I pass’d the evening at home, with Mrs: Adams who continues unwell.

28. Attended in the Senate this morning— Four of the Senators yesterday chosen, declined accepting seats in the Council, and General Skinner said he understood Mr Hayward when he should come in from Plymouth, was to resign too.— The Senate assign’d at first this forenoon to come to a choice of Counsellors from the people at large; but the house preferred 1/2 past four in the afternoon. Nothing else was done before dinner— My father and mother came to town and dined with me, as did Mr: Pickman— At 1/2 past 3. I went to the Representatives chamber in the old State house, and met the Charitable fire Society—at 4. we proceeded to the Chapel church— Dr: Elliot made the prayer— An occasional song was sung, written by T. Paine— The address to the Society, was delivered by me— Afterwards I went with several other gentlemen to Mr: A. Welles’s to tea— I soon after return’d home, and pass’d the evening with Mrs: Adams— At the close of the Evening my father and mother came to lodge here— Mr: Tudor, Mr: Quincy and Mr: James White, came as a Committee from the Society to ask a copy of my address for the press, which I accordingly furnished to Mr: Cutler the printer— It is to appear, the beginning of next week.

29. Attended this forenoon in the Senate— Seven of the Councillors elected were this day qualified in Convention of both houses, in a manner similar to that of qualifying the Governor and lieutenant Governor— After returning to their Hall, the Senate elected by ballot, their part of five standing Committees of both houses— Two Senators upon each. The Committees are, on Accounts, New Trials, Incorporation of Towns, Incorporation of parishes, and religious Societies, and on the Accounts of County Treasurers— The house propose raising another standing Committee, to consider of applications for bridges, canals and turnpike roads— Upon this the Senate did not act this day— Several petitions were read; and Mr: Tudor moved for an order to authorise the chaplains of both houses to officiate alternately in either— This was referred over to Monday— Adjourn’d to that day. 10. A.M— I called at the bankrupt-office, and proved a debt against Doctor Welsh— Called also upon Mr: Goodale and requested him to attend this afternoon at the bankrupt-office in the case of P. Phillips, as I wished to be absent. He promised to attend accordingly.— Dined at Mr: Babcock’s, with a company of Gentlemen. General Lee and his daughter were there— As were Mr: Mason, Mr: Otis &c. General Lee was in high Spirits, and full of brilliancy and wit— It was 8 o’clock before I left the table— Upon coming home, I found my father and mother were gone— I expected they would have stayed over Sunday— Quincy called just afterwards, to see them— Louisa Smith remains here.

30. Heard Mr: Emerson, morning and afternoon— Walk in the Mall towards evening— Mr: and Mrs: Smith spent an hour with us— Hall pass’d the evening, and supp’d with us— Mr: Cutler brought me the proof sheets of my address to the Charitable fire Society.

31. Attended this morning at the probate office again, in the case of M’Intire, who now in addition to his former Counsel, brought Otis with him— This multitude of Counsellors perplexes the judge very much, and he is greatly afraid that the Supreme Court will reverse his decree, because Mr Parsons tells him they will— I was obliged to go away and leave them to attend the Senate— At one O’Clock the judge had not made up his
decree— There was little business done in the Senate— In the afternoon I made a motion for a joint Committee of both houses to amend the law respecting the election of members for the house of representatives of the United States— A Committee was ordered accordingly.— Spent the Evening at home bringing up my accounts to this date.

Day. Rise generally at about 6. Walk an hour in the Mall, or elsewhere— Attend to our mathematical questions untill 9 or 10. Breakfast— From that time untill 2 p.m. at My Office or the bankrupt Office; or, now, at the Senate chamber— Dine at 2. At three return to the same places of business, and remain there untill about 7. Walk, an hour— Evening at home, at club or at the Society— Usually go to Quincy on Saturdays, and return to town on Monday Morning.
